image.altText: Several people in formal clothes smiling

props.synopsis: Trooping the Colour is usually all about the sovereign, but this time, King Charles III had to share the spotlight with his daughter-in-law Princess Catherine, who made her first public appearance in months.

title.children: Princess Catherine attends Trooping the Colour, making her first public appearance in months

image.altText: Prince Charles and Camilla at Broadbeach

props.synopsis: Luxury tropical island stays, quokka experiences, wine tours and opera performances are all being proposed for the king and queen's itinerary during their expected visit to Australia towards the end of the year.

title.children: Australian premiers are vying to host King Charles and Queen Camilla, but one expert says this state will be hard to pass up

image.altText: a woman is sitting at a table looking at a utility bill.

props.synopsis: Across Australia, a huge, forced migration is underway as consumers are shunted on to complex power prices. Just don't expect anyone to tell you about it.

title.children: A rude bill shock was the first most households heard about a monumental shift in Australia's energy system

image.altText: Police and authorities stand inspecting a helicopter crash on a sandbar.

props.synopsis: Michael James was hailed for his life-saving heroics after safely landing his damaged helicopter on a sand bank following a mid-air collision that killed four people. All of his passengers survived.

title.children: Tributes for hero pilot who crash-landed helicopter during Sea World tragedy after he dies from cancer

image.altText: Cate Campbell is surrounded by other swimmers in the pool after her race

props.synopsis: Cate Campbell has put everything she had into swimming. After her career ended in heartbreak, her competitors showed her just how much she meant to them.

title.children: Tributes flow for 'inspirational' Cate Campbell after Olympic Games bid ends

image.altText: Cate Campbell walks away

props.synopsis: Strip away the dazzling lights, pounding music and enthralled crowds that have enjoyed the Australian Swimming Trials at the Brisbane Aquatic Centre and you’re left with something pretty stark: stories of personal tragedy, personal pain and personal glory.

title.children: The soaring highs and crushing lows of the Australian Swimming Trials

image.altText: Matija Sarkic

props.synopsis: Millwall announces that 26-year-old goalkeeper Matija Sarkic, who played for Montenegro nine times, has died.

title.children: 'Immensely sad time': English football club announces the death of internationally capped goalkeeper

image.altText: Man standing on airplane steps waving.

props.synopsis: The visit is the first by a Chinese premier in seven years, and is expected to pave the way for President Xi Jinping’s first journey to Australia since 2014.

title.children: China's Premier Li Qiang says ties are 'back on track' as he arrives in Australia

image.altText: A drone shot of a large group of people gathering in boats and on surf boards in the ocean in a circle.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of people have turned out at a Perth beach on Saturday afternoon to pay tribute to brothers Jake and Callum Robinson, who were killed while on a surfing trip in Mexico.

title.children: Hundreds attend paddle-out in Perth for brothers Callum and Jake Robinson killed on Mexico surf trip

image.altText: Former 2Day FM radio presenter, Mel Greig who was part of the duo who made the infamous royal prank call in 2012.

props.synopsis: In 2012, radio host Mel Greig made a royal prank call that shocked the world. One woman took her own life; another is haunted to this day. How did the joke go so wrong?

title.children: Mel made a prank call to a hospital where Kate Middleton was a patient. The nurse who answered ended up dead

image.altText: Steven Miles David Crisafulli with a red and blue background

props.synopsis: As Annastacia Palaszczuk announced her shock resignation in December, her would-be successor Steven Miles honoured her legacy as a "great reforming Labor premier". But Labor may be aiming to leave their legacy behind them ahead of the October election.

title.children: Legacy may be a dirty word in Queensland's back-to-the-future election campaign

image.altText: An elderly Fillipino woman shuts her eyes as she recieves a vaccine

props.synopsis: The US military launched a clandestine program amid the COVID crisis to discredit China’s Sinovac inoculation – payback for Beijing’s efforts to blame Washington for the pandemic.

title.children: The Pentagon ran a secret anti-vax campaign to undermine China during the pandemic, report says

image.altText: a small creek surrounded by frosty grass

props.synopsis: Queensland's first proper cold snap this winter has hit, and as the winds drop early next week another round of frosts are likely, extending from the south all the way to the central part of the state.

title.children: Frosts have arrived late in the sunshine state this year, and they're here to stay

image.altText: A man in a beanie holds a paint palette  and brush in front of a mural of a building

props.synopsis: The North Queensland town of Bowen unveiled its first mural in the late 1980s, but preserving the art and commissioning more is an expensive challenge.

title.children: Locals call it the original 'mural capital of Australia' but the future of its street art is under threat

image.altText: A line of people swim in the blue waters of a river as a state looms over them.

props.synopsis: Contamination levels in the first eight days of June, after persistent heavy rain in Paris, showed bacteria such as E. coli and enterococci existed in the river beyond the limits judged safe for athletes.

title.children: Unsafe levels of E. coli found in Paris's Seine less than two months before Olympics

image.altText: A middle-aged African woman with glasses smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Monica Kivuti, a magistrate at the Makadara Law Courts in Kenya's capital Nairobi, was presiding over a hearing on Thursday when she was shot after rejecting a bail request for the police officer's wife.

title.children: Kenyan magistrate dies after being shot by police officer during court hearing

image.altText: Rohan Taylor talks to the media

props.synopsis: Head coach Rohan Taylor says Australia's Olympic swimmers have to trust WADA and that his team "can only control what we can control" after another alleged positive test is reported.

title.children: 'We can only control what we can control': Rohan Taylor after latest Chinese drug claims

image.altText: A large ship blasts a smaller boat with water in open ocean

props.synopsis: The Philippines has asked a United Nations body to formally recognise the extent of its undersea continental seabed in the South China Sea.

title.children: Philippines makes UN claim to exploit natural resources in contested South China Sea

image.altText: An image of an unidentifiable police officer whos head can't be seen, with their hands on their hips wearing a high vis vest.

props.synopsis: Three men with knives have assaulted workers, and stolen cash and cigarettes during two armed robberies at supermarkets in Melbourne's south-east on Saturday afternoon.

title.children: Three men with knives assault workers, steal cash and cigarettes at Melbourne supermarkets

image.altText: Jared Waerea-Hargeaves of the Roosters is sent to the sin-bin, ref holding his arms up

props.synopsis: The Sydney Roosters have survived a Parramatta comeback to defeat the Eels 28-18 and secure their eighth win of the season.

title.children: Roosters claw their way to scrappy win after Waerea-Hargeaves sin-bin sparked Eels fight back

image.altText: Hurricanes v Chiefs

props.synopsis: The Chiefs set up a Super Rugby Pacific final with the Blues after the Hamilton-based team shocked the Hurricanes 30-19.

title.children: 'We left a bit out there': Hurricanes bemoan last pass efforts as Chiefs roll into Super Rugby Pacific final

image.altText: Man stands amid protestors wearing a sign: "UK rich state, mass, fuel, poverty, and Tory, austerity, end it now.

props.synopsis: When the Conservatives took power in Britain 14 years ago, they took a butcher's knife to budget spending. It was designed to save the country, but did it break it instead?

title.children: The UK is poorer, sicker and more unsafe. Did the Conservatives break Britain?

image.altText: Cate Campbell looks down the pool

props.synopsis: Cate Campbell has reached the final of the 50 metres freestyle, giving her one last shot at making the Olympic swimming team for the Paris Games, as has pop-star turned swimmer Cody Simpson.

title.children: Cate Campbell, Cody Simpson claim final chance of Olympic selection

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: It's murder or acquittal — after five weeks of evidence and arguments, the jury in Greg Lynn's murder trial over the deaths of two Victorian campers only have two options to choose from.

title.children: Insults fly in the courtroom as Greg Lynn's double-murder trial nears its final chapter

image.altText: Vladimir Putin sits before microphones with the words NICA on the background

props.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says he will only end the war in Ukraine if Kyiv agrees to drop its NATO membership ambitions and hand over four provinces Moscow claims as its own — demands it has rejected.

title.children: Putin demands Ukraine drop NATO ambitions and hand over four provinces

image.altText: Man holds his forehead with his hand

props.synopsis: A US judge has ordered conspiracy theorist Alex Jones's personal assets be liquidated in order to pay $US1.5 billion to the families of victims from the Sandy Hook shooting, which he falsely claimed was a hoax.

title.children: Conspiracy theorist Alex Jones ordered to liquidate assets to pay families of Sandy Hook victims

image.altText: A large man wearing a grey suit speaks as he is surrounded by reporters holding microphones

props.synopsis: With Jarryd Hayne now out of jail following his sexual assault conviction being overturned, experts and advocates question whether the state's justice system is fit for purpose when it comes to sexual assault cases.

title.children: Why experts believe legal system is 'untenable' for sexual assault cases after Hayne verdict

image.altText: A head shot of John Bath

props.synopsis: Better Renting executive director Joel Dingham says sometimes even mentioning the prospect of going to tribunal can bring about a resolution.

title.children: John was told his rent was going up by $200. Then the eviction notice came

image.altText: A Sydney Swans forward points in the air, as he walks back after a goal.

props.synopsis: Joel Amartey finishes with a huge haul in Adelaide as the Sydney Swans go three games clear on top of the ladder, after the Hawks spoil Dustin Martin's milestone game at the MCG.

title.children: Nine for Amartey as Swans come from behind to crush the Crows, after Hawks beat Tigers in Dusty's 300th

image.altText: A centre pivot irrigates hay

props.synopsis: With producers across the state looking far and wide for hay at a time of below-average rainfall, the mining giant's sudden drop in production comes as a blow to the livestock industry.

title.children: WA farmers rely on Rio Tinto for one crucial resource that's suddenly been cut by half

image.altText: Image of a man kneeling on the ground with mounds of asbestos tailing waste around him. He is wearing a white singlet.

props.synopsis: In north-eastern New South Wales lies the small town of Baryulgil, where the remnants of an asbestos mine have drilled deep into the core of the community.

title.children: Years after Baryulgil's asbestos mine closed down, a deadly legacy remains with the people of this land

props.synopsis: Princess Catherine, who has been receiving preventative chemotherapy for cancer, says she will "join a few public engagements over summer", including Trooping the Colour in London on Saturday.

title.children: 'There are good days and bad days': Kate Middleton to make first public appearance as chemo continues

image.altText: A black bear sits in a cage rattling the fence.

props.synopsis: Japan recorded 219 bear attacks on people in the 12-months leading up to March this year, including six fatalities. The situation is becoming so severe that government officials have warned some bears are viewing humans as prey.

title.children: 'The bears know humans are present': How Japan's black bears became a deadly problem
